verses.text: After Abimelech, Tola the son of Puah, the son of Dodo, a man of Issachar, arose to save Israel; and he lived at Shamir in the hill country of Ephraim.
verses.comment: Tola, from the tribe of Issachar, becomes judge after Abimelech.

verses.text: He judged Israel for twenty-three years. Then he died and was buried at Shamir.
verses.comment: Tola is one of the minor judges. No detailed account of his leadership is given.

verses.text: After him arose Jair, the Gileadite, and he judged Israel for twenty-two years.
verses.comment: Jair, from Gilead, becomes judge after Tola.

verses.text: He had thirty sons who rode on thirty donkeys. They had thirty towns in the land of Gilead, which are called Havvoth-jair to this day.
verses.comment: "Havvoth-jair" means "villages of Jair." Donkey-riding is a sign of status.

verses.text: Jair died and was buried in Kamon.
verses.comment: Little is known about Kamon outside this verse.

verses.text: The Israelites again did what was evil in the sight of the LORD. They served the Baals and Ashtaroth, the gods of Aram, the gods of Sidon, the gods of Moab, the gods of the Ammonites, and the gods of the Philistines. They abandoned the LORD and did not serve him.
verses.comment: Idolatry is specifically named with gods from surrounding nations.

verses.text: So the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of the Philistines and into the hand of the Ammonites.
verses.comment: "Sold them" signifies God withdrawing protection, allowing enemies to oppress.

verses.text: They crushed and oppressed the Israelites that year. For eighteen years, all the Israelites who were beyond the Jordan in the land of the Amorites, in Gilead, were oppressed.
verses.comment: "That year" probably refers to the outbreak of oppression, continuing for 18 years.

verses.text: The Ammonites also crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah, Benjamin, and the house of Ephraim, so that Israel was greatly distressed.
verses.comment: Shows the oppression expanded westward beyond Gilead.

verses.text: The Israelites cried out to the LORD, saying, "We have sinned against you, for we have abandoned our God and served the Baals."
verses.comment: Israel's confession acknowledges their forsaking God and worshiping idols.

verses.text: The LORD said to the Israelites, "Did I not save you from the Egyptians, the Amorites, the Ammonites, the Philistines,
verses.comment: God recounts His history of salvation.

verses.text: also the Sidonians, the Amalekites, and the Maonites, when they oppressed you and you cried out to me, and I saved you from their hands?
verses.comment: "Maonites" (elsewhere called Midianites or Meunites); possible textual variation.

verses.text: But you have abandoned me and served other gods; therefore I will no longer save you.
verses.comment: God announces divine discipline for repeated apostasy.

verses.text: Go and cry out to the gods you have chosen. Let them save you in your time of trouble."
verses.comment: God's rebuke highlights the impotence of idols.

verses.text: The Israelites said to the LORD, "We have sinned. Do to us whatever seems good to you; only please deliver us this day."
verses.comment: Marks deep admission of guilt and submission to God's judgment.

verses.text: So they removed the foreign gods from among them and served the LORD. And he became troubled because of the misery of Israel.
verses.comment: "Troubled" (lit. "could endure no more"); shows God's compassion for their suffering.

verses.text: Then the Ammonites were called together and camped in Gilead, and the Israelites gathered together and camped at Mizpah.
verses.comment: Mizpah is a rallying place in Gilead for Israel's defense.

verses.text: And the leaders of Gilead said to each other, "Who is the man who will begin to fight against the Ammonites? He shall be head over all the inhabitants of Gilead."
verses.comment: Sets up the call for Jephthah in the following chapter.
